                                            By 
                                                    Matt Latimer


                                            By 
                                                    Peter Suderman


                                            By 
                                                    Vince Guerrieri


                Getty

            By 
Nick Gass

09/14/15, 11:30 AM EDT

                    Updated 09/14/15, 01:46 PM EDT
Donald Trump now has the support of nearly one-in-three likely Republican primary voters in New Hampshire, according to the results of a new Monmouth University poll released Monday.
But it's retired neurosurgeon Ben Carson — whose second-place showing represents a 12-percentage-point jump from Monmouth's July poll — who had the largest increase of any candidate.
Trump grabbed 28 percent compared with Carson's 17 percent, while Ohio Gov. John Kasich came in next with 11 percent. Texas Sen. Ted Cruz followed with 8 percent, with former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush and former tech executive Carly Fiorina each at 7 percent, Kentucky Sen. Rand Paul and Florida Sen. Marco Rubio at 4 percent. Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker and New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie drawing 2 percent, with no other candidate earning more than 1 percent and 7 percent undecided.
“Republican voters are fed up and as a result appear to be rejecting the GOP’s game plan for this nomination contest,” said Patrick Murray, Monmouth's polling director, in a release. “As with the classic episode of 'Seinfeld,' the Festivus nature of this campaign won’t be over unless the leader — in this case, Trump — is taken down. Rick Perry was the first challenger who failed in the ‘feats of strength’ against Trump.”



            By 
Nick Gass

Carson's favorability numbers dwarf the field, at 73 percent favorable to 10 percent unfavorable. It's an increase from July, when 45 percent to 15 percent saw him favorably. By comparison, Trump earned 54 percent approval to 36 percent disapproval, an improvement from the previous Monmouth poll,in July,when he stood at 47 percent to 44 percent. Cruz's favorability also jumped (50 percent to 28 percent) relative to July (44 percent to 32 percent).
Among very conservative voters, Carson leads Trump this time, 25 percent to 23 percent, with Cruz grabbing 13 percent. But Trump has gained among somewhat conservative voters, leading Carson 32 percent to 17 percent; and he leads Kasich among moderate Republicans likely to vote, 29 percent to 19 percent.
Overall, Trump's support is up 4 points, from 24 percent in the July poll.
But the fortunes of Bush and Wisconsin Gov. Scott Walker have taken a tumble. Bush, who drew 12 percent in July, went down to 7 percent this time, and Walker fell from 7 percent to 2 percent. Bush went from 47 percent to 37 percent favorability in July to 39 percent-45 percent in the latest survey. Walker, who drew 57 percent to 16 percent favorable numbers in July, experienced a decrease this time — down to 44 percent to 25 percent.
The poll was conducted via telephone from Sept. 10 to 13, surveying 415 registered voters who are likely to vote in February's GOP presidential primary. The margin of error is plus or minus 4.8 percentage points.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
title: Poll: Carson jumps 12 points in New Hampshire
